vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-20505
vulnerabilities.name: sqlite3/libsqlite3-0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Insecure Symlink Handling. 
systemd-tmpfiles in systemd through 237 mishandles symlinks present in non-terminal path components, which allows local users to obtain ownership of arbitrary files via vectors involving creation of a directory and a file under that directory, and later replacing that directory with a symlink. This occurs even if the `fs.protected_symlinks` sysctl is turned on.

## References
- [MISC](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/7986)
vulnerabilities.title: Insecure Symlink Handling
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. 
In systemd prior to 234 a race condition exists between `.mount` and `.automount` units such that automount requests from kernel may not be serviced by systemd resulting in kernel holding the mountpoint and any processes that try to use said mount will hang. A race condition like this may lead to denial of service, until mount points are unmounted.

## References
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1534701)
- [REDHAT](https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2018:0260)
- [UBUNTU](https://usn.ubuntu.com/3558-1/)
vulnerabilities.title: Denial of Service (DoS)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affected versions fo this package are vulnerable to Symlink Attack.

systemd, when updating file permissions, allows local users to change the permissions and SELinux security contexts for arbitrary files via a symlink attack on unspecified files.

## References
- [CONFIRM](http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=725357)
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=859060)
- [MLIST](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2013/10/01/9)
vulnerabilities.title: Symlink Attack
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Insecure Privilege Usage.
systemd v233 and earlier fails to safely parse usernames starting with a numeric digit (e.g. "0day"), running the service in question with root privileges rather than the user intended.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/99507)
- [CONFIRM](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/6237)
- [MLIST](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2017/07/02/1)
- [SECTRACK](http://www.securitytracker.com/id/1038839)
vulnerabilities.title: Insecure Privilege Usage
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Access Restriction Bypass.
`systemd-tmpfiles` in `systemd` before 237 attempts to support ownership/permission changes on hardlinked files even if the fs.protected_hardlinks sysctl is turned off, which allows local users to bypass intended access restrictions via vectors involving a hard link to a file for which the user lacks write access, as demonstrated by changing the ownership of the `/etc/passwd` file.

## References
- [EXPLOIT-DB](https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/43935/)
- [MISC](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/7736)
vulnerabilities.title: Access Restriction Bypass
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Jann Horn discovered that systemd's used of fgets() allowed an attacker to supply arbitrary state across systemd re-execution via systemd NotifyAccess. This can be used to improperly influence systemd execution and possibly lead to root privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-15686
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
CVE-2018-16888
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-16888
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An allocation of memory without limits, that could result in the stack clashing with another memory region, was discovered in systemd-journald when many entries are sent to the journal socket. A local attacker, or a remote one if systemd-journal-remote is used, may use this flaw to crash systemd-journald or execute code with journald privileges. Versions through v240 are vulnerable.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106525)
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2018-16865)
- [DEBIAN](https://www.debian.org/security/2019/dsa-4367)
- [MISC](https://www.qualys.com/2019/01/09/system-down/system-down.txt)
- [UBUNTU](https://usn.ubuntu.com/3855-1/)
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-16865
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An out of bounds read was discovered in systemd-journald in the way it parses log messages that terminate with a colon ':'. A local attacker can use this flaw to disclose process memory data. Versions from v221 to v239 are vulnerable.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106527)
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2018-16866)
- [DEBIAN](https://www.debian.org/security/2019/dsa-4367)
- [MISC](https://www.qualys.com/2019/01/09/system-down/system-down.txt)
- [UBUNTU](https://usn.ubuntu.com/3855-1/)
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-16866
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An allocation of memory without limits, that could result in the stack clashing with another memory region, was discovered in systemd-journald when a program with long command line arguments calls syslog. A local attacker may use this flaw to crash systemd-journald or escalate his privileges. Versions through v240 are vulnerable.

## References

- [MLIST](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2013/10/01/9)
vulnerabilities.title: Symlink Attack
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Insecure Privilege Usage.
systemd v233 and earlier fails to safely parse usernames starting with a numeric digit (e.g. "0day"), running the service in question with root privileges rather than the user intended.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/99507)
- [CONFIRM](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/6237)
- [MLIST](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2017/07/02/1)
- [SECTRACK](http://www.securitytracker.com/id/1038839)
vulnerabilities.title: Insecure Privilege Usage
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Access Restriction Bypass.
`systemd-tmpfiles` in `systemd` before 237 attempts to support ownership/permission changes on hardlinked files even if the fs.protected_hardlinks sysctl is turned off, which allows local users to bypass intended access restrictions via vectors involving a hard link to a file for which the user lacks write access, as demonstrated by changing the ownership of the `/etc/passwd` file.

## References
- [EXPLOIT-DB](https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/43935/)
- [MISC](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/7736)
vulnerabilities.title: Access Restriction Bypass
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Jann Horn discovered that systemd's used of fgets() allowed an attacker to supply arbitrary state across systemd re-execution via systemd NotifyAccess. This can be used to improperly influence systemd execution and possibly lead to root privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-15686
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
CVE-2018-16888
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-16888
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An allocation of memory without limits, that could result in the stack clashing with another memory region, was discovered in systemd-journald when many entries are sent to the journal socket. A local attacker, or a remote one if systemd-journal-remote is used, may use this flaw to crash systemd-journald or execute code with journald privileges. Versions through v240 are vulnerable.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106525)
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2018-16865)
- [DEBIAN](https://www.debian.org/security/2019/dsa-4367)
- [MISC](https://www.qualys.com/2019/01/09/system-down/system-down.txt)
- [UBUNTU](https://usn.ubuntu.com/3855-1/)
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-16865
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An out of bounds read was discovered in systemd-journald in the way it parses log messages that terminate with a colon ':'. A local attacker can use this flaw to disclose process memory data. Versions from v221 to v239 are vulnerable.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106527)
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2018-16866)
- [DEBIAN](https://www.debian.org/security/2019/dsa-4367)
- [MISC](https://www.qualys.com/2019/01/09/system-down/system-down.txt)
- [UBUNTU](https://usn.ubuntu.com/3855-1/)
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-16866
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An allocation of memory without limits, that could result in the stack clashing with another memory region, was discovered in systemd-journald when a program with long command line arguments calls syslog. A local attacker may use this flaw to crash systemd-journald or escalate his privileges. Versions through v240 are vulnerable.

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Insecure Symlink Handling. 
systemd-tmpfiles in systemd through 237 mishandles symlinks present in non-terminal path components, which allows local users to obtain ownership of arbitrary files via vectors involving creation of a directory and a file under that directory, and later replacing that directory with a symlink. This occurs even if the `fs.protected_symlinks` sysctl is turned on.

## References
- [MISC](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/7986)
vulnerabilities.title: Insecure Symlink Handling
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libudev1

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affeceted versions of this package are vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. 
In systemd prior to 234 a race condition exists between `.mount` and `.automount` units such that automount requests from kernel may not be serviced by systemd resulting in kernel holding the mountpoint and any processes that try to use said mount will hang. A race condition like this may lead to denial of service, until mount points are unmounted.

## References
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1534701)
- [REDHAT](https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2018:0260)
- [UBUNTU](https://usn.ubuntu.com/3558-1/)
vulnerabilities.title: Denial of Service (DoS)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libudev1

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Affected versions fo this package are vulnerable to Symlink Attack.

systemd, when updating file permissions, allows local users to change the permissions and SELinux security contexts for arbitrary files via a symlink attack on unspecified files.

## References

- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=859060)

Affected versions fo this package are vulnerable to Privilege Escalation.

Tar 1.15.1 does not properly warn the user when extracting setuid or setgid files, which may allow local users or remote attackers to gain privileges.

## References
- [BUGTRAQ](http://marc.info/?l=bugtraq&m=112327628230258&w=2)
vulnerabilities.title: Privilege Escalation
vulnerabilities.name: tar

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
GNU Tar through 1.30, when --sparse is used, mishandles file shrinkage during read access, which allows local users to cause a denial of service (infinite read loop in sparse_dump_region in sparse.c) by modifying a file that is supposed to be archived by a different user's process (e.g., a system backup running as root).

## References
- [MISC](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=18745431)
- [MISC](https://twitter.com/thatcks/status/1076166645708668928)
- [MISC](https://utcc.utoronto.ca/~cks/space/blog/sysadmin/TarFindingTruncateBug)
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2018-20482
vulnerabilities.name: tar

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
pax_decode_header in sparse.c in GNU Tar before 1.32 had a NULL pointer dereference when parsing certain archives that have malformed extended headers.

## References
- [MISC](http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/tar.git/commit/?id=cb07844454d8cc9fb21f53ace75975f91185a120)
- [MISC](http://savannah.gnu.org/bugs/?55369)
- [MISC](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/tar/+bug/1810241)
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2019-9923
vulnerabilities.name: tar

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
runuser in util-linux allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

## References
- [MISC](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=815922)
- [MLIST](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2016/02/27/1)
- [MLIST](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2016/02/27/2)
